title: Too many arguments / Unexpected keyword argument errors with `mypy --strict`

labels.name: change
labels.description: Suggested alteration to Pydantic, not a new feature nor a bug

body:
# Bug

Please complete:
* OS: **MacOS 10.14.6**
* Python version: **3.7.4 (default, Jul  9 2019, 18:13:23)
[Clang 10.0.1 (clang-1001.0.46.4)]**
* Pydantic version: **0.32.2**

The issue is similar to #280, but that seems to have been fixed and a part of version 0.32.2 that I've used. I also believe the cause is different.

My MWE:
```py
from pydantic.dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass(frozen=True)
class Person:
    name: str

Person(name="Bob")
```
When I type-check it with `mypy main.py`, it runs without errors, as expected. However, when I run it with `mypy --strict main.py` (or, more specifically, `mypy --no-implicit-reexport main.py`), I get 

```
error: Module 'pydantic.dataclasses' has no attribute 'dataclass'; maybe "dataclasses"?
error: Unexpected keyword argument "name" for "Person"
```
(or, similarly, for `Person("Bob")`, I get `error: Too many arguments for "Person"`)

> `--no-implicit-reexport` By default, imported values to a module are treated as exported and mypy allows other modules to import them. This flag changes the behavior to not re-export unless the item is imported using from-as or is included in `__all__`. Note this is always treated as enabled for stub files.
(https://buildmedia.readthedocs.org/media/pdf/mypy/latest/mypy.pdf, p.122)

This would lead me to believe that there's an issue with my or pydantic's imports, but it is just a theory.

For now, I hope to work around this by calling mypy without `--no-implicit-reexport`, but I suspect other people will get there when using `mypy --strict`. In general, I'd be happy to know if there's a solution to this. Thanks!
